full_title_en: Solitary Pulmonary Nodule (SPN) Malignancy Risk Score (Mayo Clinic Model)
medium_description_en: Predicts malignancy risk in solitary lung nodules on chest x-ray.
short_description_en: Risk that lung nodule is malignant.
instructions_en: Do not use in patients with prior lung cancer diagnosis or with history of extrathoracic cancer diagnosed within 5 years of nodule presentation.

seo.meta_description_en: The Solitary Pulmonary Nodule (SPN) Malignancy Risk Score predicts malignancy risk in solitary lung nodules on chest x-ray.
seo.keywords_en: solitary pulmonary nodules, SPNs, radiologically indeterminate SPNs, radiologically indeterminate solitary pulmonary nodules, clinical predictors of malignancy, radiological predictors of malignancy, lung cancer, metastasis, metastatic cancer, indeterminate pulmonary nodules, primary bronchogenic carcinoma, carcinoid tumors

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Patients with solitary lung nodule on chest x-ray.
  • Do not use in patients with prior lung cancer diagnosis or with history of extrathoracic cancer diagnosed within 5 years of nodule presentation.

next_steps.advice_en: One study (Gould 2003) suggests watchful waiting only at very low post-test probabilities (<2%), biopsy at "lower" post-test probabilities (2% to 20%), and surgery at higher post-test probabilities (>70%).

about.formula_en:
Probability of malignancy, % = 100 x ex / (1 + ex)

Probability of malignancy with FDG-PET, % = 100 / (1 + e-y)

where:

  • x = (0.0391 × age, years) + (0.1274 × nodule diameter, mm) + (0.7917 × smoker) + (1.3388 × cancer) + (0.7838 × upper lobe) + (1.0407 × spiculation) - 6.8272, 
  • y = -4.739 + (3.691 × probability of malignancy*) + 2.322 (if faint uptake), or + 4.617 (if moderate uptake), or + 4.771 (if intense uptake),

and other variables are as follows:

creator_info.about_en: Stephen J. Swensen, MD, FACR, is a radiologist and professor of radiology at Mayo Clinic. He is also the medical director of professionalism and peer support at Intermountain Healthcare in Utah. Dr. Swensen's research interests include thoracic radiology with a specific focus on lung cancer screening with CT and radiologic analysis of lung nodules and masses.
